Fig. 1 (a) H2-TPR curves of YMO+Pt/SA; XRD patterns of fresh (a) and hydrothermal aged (b) YMO+Pt/SA and redox-treated YMO+Pt/SA with the oxidation at 800 °C and the reduction at different temperature of 200 °C, 250 °C, 300 °C. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns (a) and amplified Pt(111) diffraction peak (b) of catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Bright-field TEM images and the corresponding particle size distribution histograms are inserted on YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi (a) and YMO+Pt/SA-Red (b); TEM-EDS mapping on different region (c) and (d) on YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi and YMO+Pt/SA-Red (e), where the red color represent Pt (c1,d1 and e1), blue color represent Mn(c2,d2,e2). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 The CO adsorbed DRIFT spectra on YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi (a) and YMO+Pt/SA-Red (b) with an increased adsorption time up to saturation coverage in the flow of 1 vol% CO/N2 at room temperature; The compared spectra (c) after purging in He flow; The variation in intensity of linear Pt-CO band at the range of 2093–2099 cm−1) as the function of time. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Al 2p or Pt 4 f curves (a) and O1s curves (b), EPR profiles (c), and Raman spectra (d) of catalysts. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 (a) H2-TPR cycle curves: The sample with pretreatment in N2 flow are labeled as 1st, and then cooling down in H2/N2 flow, the sample is labeled as 2nd. Finally, the test sample with oxidation pretreatment at 800 °C is labeled as Reoxdiation; (b) Initial H2 consumption rate versus inverse temperature of catalysts at first reduction. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 in situ DRIFTs of adsorbed reaction gases on YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi(left) and YMO+Pt/SA-Red(right), A and B are recorded as the function of adsorbed time in the flow of CO+C3H6 +NO at 50 °C; C and D are recorded as the function of adsorbed time in the flow of CO+C3H6 +NO+O2 at 50 °C; E and F are recorded as the function of temperature in the flow of CO+C3H6 +NO+O2. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 The intensity of adsorbed nitrate species (1629 cm−1, 1594 cm−1, 1398 cm−1) and monodentate nitrite species (1470 cm−1) as a function of temperature. Solid lines and dot lines are assigned to YMO+Pt/SA-Red(right Y axis) and YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi(left Y axis), respectively. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 The catalytic conversion of CO(a), C3H6(b) and NO(c) as functions of reaction temperatures over different catalysts. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Relative TOF profiles of CO, C3H6 and NO at different temperatures of YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi and YMO+Pt/SA-Red. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 CO(a), C3H6(b) and NO(c) conversion on hydrothermal aging catalysts. Fig. 11 Fig. 12 Schematic diagrams about the evolution process of complex reaction molecules on platinum site and oxygen sites (surficial active oxygen Ox -, surficial oxygen vacancies) for the YMn2O5 modified Pt-based catalysts. Fig. 12 Table 1 Summary of XPS analysis. To improve the stability of Pt nanoparticles, the redox cycles with oxidation at 800 °C and reduction at 250 °C for three times were adopted on the Mn-mullite doped Pt-based catalysts (Pt-YMO/SA-Red) to rearrange the Pt atoms. The light-off temperature toward CO/C3H6/NO oxidation on Pt-YMO/SA-Red decreases by 20–60 °C, and the NO maximum conversion is improved by 27 % than the catalyst with only oxidation treatment at 800 °C (Pt-YMO/SA-Oxi). Characterization results verify that the interaction of Pt with YMn2O5 on Pt-YMO/SA-Red is reinforced via redox cyclic treatment to inhibit the aggregation of platinum particles and promote the formation of active oxygen species, in comparison to Pt-YMO/SA-Oxi. The easier active oxygen regeneration and more active platinum sites contribute to the excellent catalytic performances and stability. In addition, the mechanism for the high CO/C3H6/NO oxidation performance are analyzed via the detected reaction intermediate species. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Diesel oxidation catalyst Redox cycles Atomic rearrangement Oxidation performance 1 Introduction Eliminating vehicle emission has attracted considerable attention due to the serious concern in human health and environment [1]. Especially for the harmful exhaust like CO, HC and NO, supported platinum-based catalysts with high efficiency has been widely used as diesel oxidation catalysts (DOC) in the beginning of diesel aftertreatment system [2,3]. In considering to the regeneration of diesel particle filter (DPF) next to DOC, the periodically raising temperature could be up to 600 °C, which requires high temperature stability of DOC [4,5]. Small Pt particles with higher surface energy have a strong sintering tendency to form the larger particles via the grain boundary mobilities when working under the elevated temperature [6,7]. Such a phenomenon leads to a reduction of exposed sites, along with the degradation of catalytic activity significantly [8]. To enhance the sintering resistance of noble metal, there have developed methods to modify the support or metal particles and adopt the treatment techniques based on the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) to inhibit the migration of platinum atoms [9–12]. The latter aspect is particularly effective from physical and chemical barriers to anchor platinum nanoparticles, especially for thermal treatment in different atmosphere. As reported from Liu group [13], the oxide layer to encapsulate Au nanoparticle after calcination at 800 °C in air to obtain the ultra-stable catalyst. Meanwhile, the reducible support could form the dynamic overlayer to encapsulate the noble-metal nanoparticles during the switch between reduction and oxidation atmospheres at elevated temperatures, such as Au/TiO2 [14], Pt/FeOx [15]. To avoid the structural instability of catalyst, the oxidation temperature is expected to reach up to 800 °C. Perovskite and mullite has the high stability forming at least 800 °C, which are potential in improving the stability of catalysts. Wang et al. [16] firstly reported that the Mn-mullite towards NO oxidation performance were excellent. Especially, the coexistence of Mn4+ and Mn3+ on Mn-mullite are centered in the MnO5 pyramidal (Mnpyr) and MnO6 octahedral (Mnoct), respectively. Then two active sites that oxygen vacancy tetrahedron is linked to a square pyramid (Mnpyr-Mntet) and octahedron (Mnoct-Mntet) assist in activating O2 molecules and are furtherly favorable for the NO oxidation [17,18], enlightening the combination of Pt on Mn-mullite for the better oxidation performance. However, the synergistic effect of Pt with Mn-mullite is rarely reported. Recently, Mao et al. [19] developed the high-temperature (800 °C) redox cycling to construct the strong bonding interactions between metal and perovskite. It is possibly for the Mn-mullite modified Pt-based catalyst to anchor platinum on stable mullite at 800 °C via redox cycle. According to the surficial reduction temperature of MnOx below 600 °C [20,21], the high reduction temperature is inevitable for the destroy of Mn-mullite. To ensure the Mn-mullite phase favorable of NO oxidation [18], it could construct the surficial defect at low reduction temperature by oxygen removal, which is beneficial to trap the volatile platinum atom at 800 °C [22–24]. In this study, oxidation-reduction cyclical treatment is developed on Mn-mullite modified Pt-based catalyst with oxidation treatment at high temperature and reduction at low temperature. It is expected to stabilize the structure and produce the surficial defect to capture the platinum species. The screening about the promoted effect on platinum aggregation with different reduction temperature is considered. Then further characterizations would be proved that the strong Pt and Mn-mullite interaction helps the stability of platinum species and improve the catalytic performance. 2 Experimental section 2.1 catalysts preparation YMn2O5 with the atomic ratio of Mn/Y= 2 was prepared with co-precipitation method. Appropriate amounts of Pluronic F127 is dissolved in deionized water. Then, Mn(CH3CO2)2.4 H2O and Y(NO3)3.6 H2O are added and stir well. The solution gradually gets brown with the pH= 8 by adding NH3·H2O. With the dropwise of H2O2(30 %), mixed solution gets black and continuously stirred for 6 h. After centrifugation and dried at 105 °C for 12 h, the sample is calcined at 800 °C for 4 h in air to obtain YMn2O5, which is labeled as YMO. The preparation of YMO+Pt/SA: Based on the previous work [25], the carbonization Pt(1 mass%) supported on SiO2-Al2O3 materials(Solvay) physically mixed with YMO(5 mass%) and ball-milling for coating onto the cylindrical cordierite monoliths (2.5 cm3, 400 cells per square inch, Corning Ltd., USA). After being dried at 60 °C and calcined at 550 °C for 3 h in the air, the monolithic catalyst with a total wash-coated loading amount of 150 g/L is obtained. The sample YMO+Pt/SA is oxidized at 800 °C for 1 h in 5 vol% O2/N2, which is labeled as YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi. Meanwhile, the sample YMO+Pt/SA is oxidized at 800 °C for 10 min in 5 vol% O2/N2 and 250 °C for 10 min in 5 vol% H2/N2 with three redox cycles, which is labeled as YMO+Pt/SA-Red. For the choice of reduction temperature, 200 °C and 300 °C are also considered to obtained the smallest platinum particles. Hydrothermal aging condition: 800 °C for 10 h in 10 % H2O/air. 2.2 catalysts characterization Hydrogen-temperature programmed reduction(H2-TPR) was conducted in a quartz micro-reactor and the front of detector (TCD) is equipped with a drying tube (CaCl2) to trap water. After pretreating at 450 °C for 30 min in N2 flow and cooling to room temperature, 0.1 g sample was exposed to a flow of 5 vol% H2/N2 mixture and heated at a rate of 10 °C/min. XRD analyses were conducted using a Rigaku (Ultima IV) X-ray diffractometer, equipped with Cu Kα radiation, which is operated at 40 kV and 40 mA with a 0.02° step size scanning from 10° to 80°(2θ). TEM images were performed by using JEM-2100 F (JEOL, Japanese) with an accelerating voltage of 200 KV. EDS-Mapping images were obtained from Titan G2 60–300 (FEI Company, USA). CO adsorbed DRIFT spectra was performed on a Niclolet 6700 spectrometer at atmospheric pressure. Before exposed to 1 vol% CO/N2 at room temperature till saturation coverage, the sample was reduced at 450 °C for 30 min in 5 vol% H2/N2. Then the He flow was introduced to purge the gas CO. The spectra were recorded with a resolution of 4 cm−1 and 64 scans. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS) data were performed with an electron spectrometer (AXI Sultra DLD, Shimadzu Co.) equipped with an Al Kα radiation as a primary excitation. Binding energies were calculated on the basis of C 1 s at 284.6 eV. Raman spectra were collected using a Renishaw in Via Reflex Raman spectrometer (Yvon Dxi, Thermofisher) with 532 nm excitation wavelength, and the frequency collected is in the range of 200–800 cm−1. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra of catalysts were obtained by JEOL JES-FA200 spectrometer at 25 °C. In situ DRIFTs spectra were obtained on Niclolet 6700 spectrometer equipped with mercury-cadmium-telluride (MCT) detector cooled by liquid nitrogen and the reaction cell with KBr windows. Prior to each experiment, the catalyst is pretreated at 450 °C for 30 min in He and cooling down. The mixed reaction gases include the flow of 5000 ppm CO, 1600 ppm C3H6, 1000 ppm NO, N2 balance with 300 ml/min. The spectra are recorded at different adsorption time from 1 min to 20 min and by accumulating 60 scans with a resolution of 4 cm−1. Then 5 % O2/N2 are introduced to the system with the total flow rate of 300 ml/min. The spectra were collected at different reaction temperature from 50 °C to 350 °C. Then the Background spectra were subtracted from the sample spectra in Kubelka-Munk (KM) units at the corresponding reaction temperature. 2.3 Catalytic measurements The catalytic activities of monolithic catalysts were evaluated by CO, C3H6 and NO oxidation using continuous-flow fix-bed reactor operated at atmospheric pressure. The feed gas was 200 ppm NO, 330 ppm C3H6, 1000 ppm CO, 10 vol% O2, 7 vol% H2O, and 8 vol% CO2 and balanced by N2 with a 2500 ml/min flow rate and 60 kh−1 space velocity. A pretreatment under reaction mixture are applied at 550 °C for 1 h before the catalytic tests. The concentration of reaction mixture is online analyzed with FTIR analyzer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Antaris IGS-6700) and the reactant conversion was defined by the following Eqs. (1), (2) and (3): (1) CO conversion= ([CO]inlet -[CO]outlet)/[CO]inlet*100 % (2) C3H6 conversion= ([C3H6]inlet -[ C3H6]outlet)/[ C3H6]inlet*100 % (3) NO conversion= [NO2]outlet/[NOx]outlet*100 % Where the subscript as inlet and outlet stands for the inlet concentration and the outlet concentration, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural properties of platinum particles The designed redox-treatment to strengthen the interaction of Pt with YMO, which is aimed at the construction of surficial defect at low reduction temperature for anchoring platinum atoms at high oxidation temperature. For YMO+Pt/SA, Fig. 1(a) shows a weak reduction peak at the lower temperature (172 °C) and two main reduction peaks above 200 °C, which are assigned to the reduction of platinum oxides and manganese oxide (Mn4+→Mn3+→Mn2+), respectively. To avoid the transformation from MnO2 to Mn2O3 phase, the reduction temperature could be lower than 289 °C. Then, the different reduction temperature at 200 °C, 250 °C and 300 °C are adopted to investigate the variation of platinum in structural properties. Fig. 2(b) presents the diffraction peaks of fresh catalysts. It could be found that YMO+Pt/SA with oxidation treatment at 800 °C and then reduction treatment at 300 °C appears the phase different with YMn2O5, indicating that the reduction temperature above 250 °C could destroy the YMn2O5 phase and decompose to Y2O3 and Mn2O3. But it could recover the YMn2O5 phase without impurity after hydrothermal treatment at 800 °C for 10 h in 10 vol% H2O/air. Pay attention to the characteristic diffraction peak of Pt(111) at 2θ= 39.7°, the platinum particles on YMO+Pt/SA treated at 800 °C in oxidation atmosphere all clearly aggregated with a stronger diffraction intensity. And the platinum particles further grown up after hydrothermal treatment. The phenomenon indicates the strong Pt(111) diffraction intensity is consistent to the aggregation degree of platinum nanoparticles. Increasing with the reduction temperature, the Pt(111) diffraction intensity presents the firstly decreased and then increased trends. In comparison to the redox-treated catalysts at reduction temperature, 250 °C is likely the special point that has the relatively weaker platinum diffraction peak intensity before and after aging. The results indicate that the catalyst with the oxidation treatment at 800 °C and reduction treatment at 250 °C could reflect the stability due to the stronger interaction of Pt with YMn2O5 via atom arrangement. To exclude the effect of high temperature (800 °C) on platinum dispersion, YMO+Pt/SA is treated at 800 °C in oxidation atmosphere. Fig. 2(a) displays the diffraction patterns of YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi and YMO+Pt/SA-Red. The diffraction peaks of support material (Al2O3) on all catalysts are mainly at 45.5° and 67.1° assigned to the γ-Al2O3, which are overlapped with the diffraction of YMn2O5 and Pt, respectively. The aggregate degree of platinum on YMO+Pt/SA-Red is smaller than YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi, confirming the higher platinum dispersion on YMO+Pt/SA-Red which is favorable of the adsorption and activation of reaction gases. This region at 2θ= 39–41° is amplified in Fig. 2(b) to intuitively compare the location of diffraction peak and diffraction intensity. The location of Pt(111) standard card is at 39.76°, and the expansion or contraction of unit cell would lead to the excursion of diffraction peak. Due to the same oxidation treatment at 800 °C, the 2θ of Pt(111) is at 39.9° on fresh catalysts. The shift verifies the strong interaction of Pt with YMn2O5 due to the redispersion of Pt atoms at 800 °C, resulting in the shift to a higher angle. The weaker intensity on YMO+Pt/SA-Red could be contributed to the anchor effect at the defect sites to avail the Pt redispersion, while the platinum atom could aggregate to the larger particle on YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi. More detailed structural analysis of platinum would be investigated the lower platinum aggregation degree after redox treatment. TEM images and related particle size distribution of catalysts are presented as in Fig. 3(a-b). According to the Bright-field TEM images, the black circles are assigned to platinum nanoparticles and it could be found the more platinum particles appearing on YMO+Pt/SA-Red at the same scale (50 nm). The platinum particle size distribution is presented as histogram after statistically calculating via collecting above 60 particles. The average platinum particle size of YMO+Pt/SA-Red is 7.3 nm with the dispersion of 16 % [8], which is smaller than of YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi (8.5 nm) with the corresponding platinum dispersion of 14 %. It is in accordance with the results of Pt(111) diffraction intensity. EDS-mapping are given to reflect the distribution of elements. The detected YMn2O5 particle on YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi in Fig. 3(c) is relatively larger than platinum particle with the agglomeration of Mn element in Fig. 3(c2). In comparison to region existing the platinum particles in Fig. 3(d) and (e), the obvious agglomeration of platinum element is detected in Fig. 3(d1) and (e1), and Mn element is well-dispersing in Fig. 3(d2) and (e2). It could be found that platinum particles on YMO+Pt/SA-Red is smaller than on YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi, verifying the resistance of platinum sintering with the redox treatment. In the practical reaction process, smaller platinum particles are closely to the exposed platinum sites. The surficial exposed platinum sites could be detected using CO as the probe molecule. To clearly reflect the surficial platinum sites, the catalysts are reduced at 450 °C to ensure the metallic platinum. With the introduction of CO molecule, the strong linear Pt-CO peak at around 2000–2100 cm−1 appears at 1 min. Increasing with the adsorption time, two peaks at the range of 2100–2200 cm−1 belonging to the vibration of CO and linear Pt-CO peak are gradually stronger. In comparison to Fig. 4(a) and (b), the increased rate of adsorption on YMO+Pt/SA-Red is likely more quickly than YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi, indicating its higher dispersion. After purging in He flow, the band about CO molecule is disappeared and the adsorbed intensity decreased due to the removal of physical adsorption. In Fig. 4(c), YMO+Pt/SA-Red has a strong vibration band at 2093 cm−1 and a shoulder band at 2056 cm−1, as well as a single peak at 2098 cm−1 appearing on YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi. The shift to a lower wavenumber implies the higher electronic density of platinum on YMO+Pt/SA-Red for the final reduction step. Meanwhile, the difference observed in peak shape could speculate that the platinum particles are structure sensitivity. Kale et al. [26] have reported that there has two vibration peaks at the well-coordinated sites (high-frequency vibrational mode) and under-coordinated sites(low-frequency mode) when CO adsorbed to Pt nanoparticle, where the fraction of WC sites increases with platinum particle size. The platinum particles on the YMO+Pt/SA-Red posse a mass of WC and partial UC sites, yet the main WC sites on YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi, displaying the smaller platinum particles on YMO+Pt/SA-Red. Moreover, the variation in the Pt-CO intensity is presented in Fig. 4(d), which is positively correlated to the exposed platinum sites. Intuitively, the Pt-CO adsorbed intensity on YMO+Pt/SA-Red is higher at saturation coverage and after purging, suggesting the more surficial platinum sites on YMO+Pt/SA-Red, as concluded in TEM results. XPS patterns of Pt 4 f or Al 2p and O1s are shown in Fig. 5(a) and (b). Fig. 5(a) includes the six well-fitted peaks about platinum species with binding energies of 70.9/74.2 eV, 73.6/76.9 eV and 74.8/78.1 eV, which are attributed to Pt0 4 f7/2/4 f5/2, Pt2+4 f7/2/4 f5/2 and Pt4+4 f7/2/4 f5/2, respectively [27,28]. According to the areas of fitted peaks, Table 1 lists the relative precent ratio of Pt0 with 48.8 % on YMO+Pt/SA-Red, improved by around 11.2 % than on YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi. More metallic platinum formation would be the reduction treatment, which is in line with the red-shift in linear Pt-CO vibration band. For YMO+Pt/SA-Red, it has undergone the oxidation treatment at 800 °C and reduction treatment at 250 °C with third cycle. The cyclical redox treatment is expected to stabilize the platinum nanoparticles via strengthening the interaction of Pt with YMO, along with the production of active oxygen species (O-, O2 -, O2 2-) [29]. Fig. 4(b) divides the O1s peak into 531.5 eV and 532.8 eV, which are assigned to chemisorbed oxygen or oxygen vacancy species (Oα) and lattice oxygen species (Oβ) [30], respectively. By calculating the peak area ratio in Table 1, there is a 10 % higher Oα amount existing on YMO+Pt/SA-Red, verifying the promotion effect of active oxygen species on enhancing the interaction of Pt with YMO. Fig. 5(c) displays the electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) profiles of catalysts. A symmetrical signal peak at g= 1.999 is belonged to unpaired electrons at the oxygen vacancy sites. It could be observed that YMO+Pt/SA-Red exhibits a relatively stronger signal, also confirming its more oxygen vacancies. Raman spectra of the catalysts are presented in Fig. 5(d) with the range of 550–800 cm−1. There are two main peaks at 615 cm−1 and 670 cm−1 on YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi, which are assigned to the Mn-O stretching vibrations of pyramidal MnO5 and octahedral MnO6 on YMn2O5, respectively [31]. The analysis indicates the presence of only pure mullite phase, in line with the XRD phase. The lower vibration intensity on YMO+Pt/SA-Red indicates a relatively lesser amount of Mn-O due to the reduction pretreatment. The reducibility of catalysts is investigated by H2-TPR experiments in Fig. 6. The reduction temperature is from 30 °C to 800 °C to YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi has two consecutive reduction peak at 338 and 535 °C, which are attributed to the reduction of Mn4+→Mn3+, Mn3+→Mn2+ in the YMn2O5, respectively [32]. For YMO+Pt/SA-Red, a main reduction peak at 343 °C with a weak shoulder peak at 397 °C. The lower reduction peak temperature might be the interaction of Pt with YMO to weaken the oxygen bond intensity. Comparing to the reduction peak temperature on YMO+Pt/SA at 289 °C and 395 °C, the only oxidation treatment at 800 °C and cyclic oxidation (800 °C)-reduction (250 °C) treatment could strengthen the metal-oxygen bond ability of YMO+Pt/SA, resulting in their higher reduction peak temperature. After this reduction process, the catalyst is cooled down and reduced secondly. In Fig. 6(a), no obvious reduction peak is detected. At the first reduction, the initial H2 consumption rate is calculated, as shown in Fig. 6(b). It could be observed that YMO+Pt/SA-Red has a higher H2 initial consumption rate, indicating its better oxygen mobility. Meanwhile, the lower reduction temperature on YMO+Pt/SA-Red at initial stage most likely be connected to the relatively smaller platinum particles than on YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi. The regeneration of surficial active oxygen species (O2 -, O- and O2-) could evaluated by cycled H2-TPR. The catalysts is pre-oxidized at 450 °C to supplement the oxygen species, at which there would form the relatively weaker metal-oxygen bond or the lower chemical state of metal. Thus, the lower reduction peak temperature could be observed. Consequently, a single reduction peak is presented at 270–280 °C, verifying the re-oxidization of metallic platinum and partial Mnn+, which are assigned to the reduction of surficial active oxygen species. By integrating the reduction amount, the reduction peak area recovered by 36.3 % and 48.3 % than at 1st reduction on YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi and YMO+Pt/SA-Red, respectively. It could be concluded that the active surficial oxidation species on YMO+Pt/SA-Red are more easily regenerated, confirming that the redox treatment could produce the formation of active surficial oxygen species. In situ DRIFTs are performed to monitor the adsorption and oxidation process of reaction molecules as a function of time and temperature, as displayed in Fig. 7, including three steps in the reaction process. (i) the mixed reaction gas (CO, C3H6, NO) are introduced in the surface of catalysts at 50 °C to reveal the competed adsorption ability and the amount of surficial active oxygen species. (ii) The introduction of 5 % O2/N2 in the feed gas is to reflect the variation of adsorption species in practical rich oxygen condition. (iii) The reaction temperature is elevated to monitor the evolution process of intermediates. Fig. 7(a) and (b) show the spectra of CO+C3H6 +NO adsorption at 50 °C from 1 min to 20 min. The peak at 1639 cm−1 and 1657 cm−1 assigning to carboxylate, might include partial nitrates due to the overlapped region of carboxylate species and nitrates [33,34]. The broad peak during 3000–3500 cm−1 assigning to -OH first appear at 1 min [35]. At 3 min, peak that have been associated with an -C-H might for formate species at 2900–3100 cm−1, gas CO at 2117 cm−1 and 2174 cm−1, linear Pt-CO at 2094 cm−1 and acetate at 1441 cm−1 are evident [36–38]. With an increased adsorbed time, these peaks are gradually stronger. No obvious peak of linear Pt-CO on YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi, which could be explained for the lesser exposed platinum sites to provide the adsorption sites for CO than on YMO+Pt/SA-Red. Meanwhile, the higher intensity of -OH in Fig. 7(B) is clear evidence that more C3H6 are converted via surficial active oxygen species of YMO+Pt/SA-Red. It seems that the adsorption of CO and C3H6 on Pt and YMO could be activated to form formate, carboxylate and acetate species at low-temperature. The competitive oxidation of CO, C3H6 and NO result in the hysteresis effect of nitrates species [39]. The catalysts are exposed to CO+C3H6 +NO+O2 flow and the resulting spectra as a function of time are shown in Fig. 7 C and D. Immediately, the intermediates of CO and C3H6 oxidation, formats and acetate species, disappear at 1 min, suggesting the rapid reaction and decomposition to CO2. These residual adsorption sites could promote the adsorption of NO to form related intermediates. Thus, bridged nitrates (1,630 cm−1) [8], chelating nitrates (1,590 cm−1) [40], nitro compound (1,444 cm−1) [41] and monodentate nitrates (1,552 cm−1, 1,314 cm−1) [33,42] appear at 10 min and then present the increased trend with adsorption time. At 15 min, it is obvious for the depletion of the -OH feature at 3,740 cm−1 on Pt-YMO/SA-Red, inferring that the acid sites on the alumina support react with adsorbed species. In Fig. 7(D), the intensity about Pt-CO gradually decreases over long oxygen exposures, which might be the partial CO adsorbed on platinum sites participate in CO oxidation reaction. To compare the amount of nitrates, it concludes that the reaction gases on Pt-YMO/SA-Red could react more easily promoting the formation of intermediates than on Pt-YMO/SA-Oxi. Then the spectra as a function of temperature are shown in Fig. 7E and F, where mainly present the intermediates of NO oxidation. From 100° to 150 °C, the adsorption bands about monodentate nitrates and nitro compound are disappeared. At 150 °C, the ionic nitrates appear and the increased intensity with the elevated temperature up to 190 °C. Simultaneously, monodentate nitrites (1,466 cm−1) [42,43] is detected with the reduction of ionic nitrates (1,398 cm−1). Meanwhile, the band of linear Pt-CO greatly shift to a higher wavenumber due to the oxidation of platinum in rich oxygen at high temperature. With the increased temperature, bridged nitrates gradually transform to chelating nitrates. To clearly understand the difference in intermediates during the reaction process from low-temperature to high-temperature, there are collected the intensity on four kinds of bands, including adsorbed bridged nitrates (1629 cm−1), chelating nitrates (1,594 cm−1), ionic nitrates (1,398 cm−1) and monodentate nitrite (1,470 cm−1), during the range of 100–350 °C in Fig. 8. All species presents the parabola relation due to the thermodynamics equilibrium of NO oxidation. It could be found that bridged/chelating nitrates and monodentate nitrite/ionic nitrates are synchronously varied in intensity, respectively. In comparison, those peak temperature on YMO+Pt/SA-Red are about 210 °C, which is lower than 250 °C on YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi. Meanwhile, a much more intermediates exist on YMO+Pt/SA-Red catalysts. It displays the higher NO conversion and lower light-off temperature on YMO+Pt/SA-Red as associated with the catalytic performance. 3.2 Catalytic performance The compared catalytic performance of catalysts are presented in Fig. 9. The conversion temperature and NO maximum conversion of original catalysts without pretreatment are great due to the lower final calcinated temperature. To improve the stability of catalyst, it is necessary to pretreat catalyst at the high-temperature. Thus, except for one with the oxidation treatment at high temperature, another catalyst undergoes the redox treatment with three cycles in oxidation treatment at high-temperature and reduction treatment at low-temperature. When oxidation pretreatment at 800 °C, it is obviously degraded for catalytic performance on YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi with a higher conversion temperature and a lower NO maximum conversion. While for the redox catalyst undergoing the oxidation (800 °C) and reduction (250 °C) treatment, the conversion temperature is relatively lower and the NO maximum conversion is higher than the catalysts with only oxidation pretreatment. As listed in Table 2, the temperature of full conversion (T90, the temperature of 90 % conversion) of CO/C3H6 and the light-off temperature (T20, the temperature of 20 % conversion) of NO on YMO+Pt/SA-Red deceased by around 20 °C and 60 °C, respectively. And the NO maximum conversion on YMO+Pt/SA-Red is twice than on YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi. The great distinction on catalysts confirm that the oxidation-reduction cycle is beneficial to strengthen the interfacial effect of Pt with YMn2O5. To further unravel the differences of catalytic oxidation activity with platinum active sites, kinetic data for CO, C3H6 and NO oxidation are given in Fig. 10. To exclude the heat and mass transfer phenomena, there have adopted reactant conversion below 15 % [44]. The turnover frequency (TOF) value of CO, C3H6 and NO at different temperature are calculated. When TOF values are basically same at 0.5–0.6 s−1 in all reactions, there appears a big gap in temperature. It could be seen that a lower conversion temperature appears on YMO+Pt/SA-Red, decreasing by 10 °C for CO oxidation, 19 °C for C3H6 oxidation and 37 °C for NO oxidation, respectively, than on YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi. This might be the more active platinum sites on YMO+Pt/SA-Red facilitate the oxidation reaction at the lower temperature. 3.3 Hydrothermal stability The stability test of catalysts is important in practical application. Meanwhile, there has high level of water vapor in diesel emission, which largely affect the catalytic performance. Thus, the catalysts with hydrothermal aging are greatly equivale with the mileage life of catalysts. After severely ageing at 800 °C for 10 h in a flow of 10 % H2O/air, the CO/C3H6/NO conversion on both aged catalysts show a reduced trend in Fig. 11. It could be observed that YMO+Pt/SA-Red(800HA) has a relatively lower light-off temperature than YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi(800HA). While for NO oxidation reaction, the light-off temperature on YMO+Pt/SA-Red(800HA) is lower by about 23 °C than on YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi(800HA), and a slightly higher NO maximum conversion at 28 % which is higher than the 20 % NO conversion catalyzed by hydrothermally aged Pd/SiO2 @Zr (800 °C/10 h, 10 % O2, 5 % H2O, 5 % CO2/Ar) [45]. The more superior catalytic performance of YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi(800HA) verified its higher stability. 3.4 Reaction mechanism It is usually thought that CO/C3H6/NO oxidation obeys the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism [46], the CO/C3H6 and NO oxidation process are different, especially for the activation of reactant molecule. The probable chemical adsorption and activation mechanism of CO, C3H6 and NO on the YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi and YMO+Pt/SA-Red catalysts are summarized in Fig. 12. When the catalyst is exposed CO and C3H6 under without O2 flow, the oxygen vacancies on catalyst could react with the adsorbed CO or C3H6 and form the intermediate species of formates and carboxylates. The introduced O2 molecule reacts with oxygen vacancies to produce the surficial active oxygen (Ox -), which plays a crucial role in transforming the intermediates to CO2 and H2O. In the case of NO oxidation process, the adsorption and activation of oxygen is the rate determining step [47]. Oxygen molecule is activated by oxygen vancies to form surficial active oxygen (Ox -). Then adsorbed NO directly reacts with the surficial active oxygen (Ox -), not oxygen vacancies, to form the main chelating/bridging nitrates and then to decompose at high temperature. The main difference between YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi and YMO+Pt/SA-Red are reflected in the amount of oxygen vacancies. In comparison to the only oxidation treated YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi catalyst, YMO+Pt/SA-Red catalyst is obtained by oxygen-reduction cyclic treatment, which produces much oxygen vacancies and owes the stronger oxygen complementary ability, fascinating the formation of surficial active oxygen (Ox -). Meanwhile, the exposed platinum sites on YMO+Pt/SA-Red are higher than on YMO+Pt/SA-Oxi, due to the atom rearrangement in oxygen (high temperature)-reduction (low temperature) cyclic process. Thus, much more formate and carboxylate intermediates appear via reacting with oxygen vacancies on YMO+Pt/SA-Red under oxygen-free condition, and quickly decompose to small molecules with the doping of O2. And the formation of Ox - promotes the production of much nitrates in rich O2 condition, which is favor of the higher NO conversion. 4 Conclusion In this work, we developed the convenient way to improve the resistance of Pt sintering via oxidation (800 °C) and reduction (250 °C) cycle via atom arrangement. The reduction at low temperature could construct the surficial defect, which is beneficial for capturing platinum atom with oxidation at high temperature. The smaller platinum particles and higher active oxygen species are contributed to the excellent catalytic performance for CO/C3H6/NO oxidation, even following harsh hydrothermal stability. It demonstrates the strong interactions between Pt and Mn-mullite via redox cyclic treatment, which is potential to stabilize the platinum nanoparticles in supported catalysts. coredata.dc:description: To improve the stability of Pt nanoparticles, the redox cycles with oxidation at 800 °C and reduction at 250 °C for three times were adopted on the Mn-mullite doped Pt-based catalysts (Pt-YMO/SA-Red) to rearrange the Pt atoms. The light-off temperature toward CO/C3H6/NO oxidation on Pt-YMO/SA-Red decreases by 20–60 °C, and the NO maximum conversion is improved by 27 % than the catalyst with only oxidation treatment at 800 °C (Pt-YMO/SA-Oxi). Characterization results verify that the interaction of Pt with YMn2O5 on Pt-YMO/SA-Red is reinforced via redox cyclic treatment to inhibit the aggregation of platinum particles and promote the formation of active oxygen species, in comparison to Pt-YMO/SA-Oxi. The easier active oxygen regeneration and more active platinum sites contribute to the excellent catalytic performances and stability. In addition, the mechanism for the high CO/C3H6/NO oxidation performance are analyzed via the detected reaction intermediate species.
coredata.dc:title: Atomic rearrangement on YMn2O5 modified Pt-based diesel oxidation catalyst for promoted performance
